entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 7:22PM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
At 722 PM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Zephyr, or 7 miles southeast of Early, moving east at 30 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 30 mph and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
This storm will remain over mainly rural areas of north central Mills and south central Comanche Counties, including the following locations... Priddy, Democrat, and Newburg.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 7 at 5:14PM PST until March 7 at 6:45PM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
FFWSGX
The National Weather Service in San Diego has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... San Bernardino County in southern California...
* Until 645 PM PST.
* At 514 PM PST, Doppler radar indicated showers and thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.5 and 0.75 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.25 to 0.75 inches in 60 minutes. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Fontana, Ontario, Rialto, Chino, Rancho Cucamonga, Upland, Montclair, San Antonio Heights, Mira Loma and Glen Avon.

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 6:45 PM PST. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 6:45 PM PST. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:36PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
A developing moisture band over the North Pacific will stream northeast and into the panhandle starting mid next week. Rainfall total are looking moderate to heavy with 24 hour totals in the 1 to 2 inch range. The main item to watch is a nose of warmer air will move into the panhandle that will push freezing levels over 5000 feet across the southern panhandle and 1000 to 2000 over the north central panhandle.
The item to keep an eye on is additional snow melt from warming along with the rainfall of the heavier rainfall that stream flow will have higher water levels. We will continue to maintain a watch over this potential hazardous situation.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 7 at 7:02PM EST until March 9 at 9:00AM EST by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Vermont...
Otter Creek At Center Rutland affecting Rutland County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Otter Creek at Center Rutland.
* WHEN...Until late Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, There will be field flooding along Otter Creek from Clarendon downstream to Pittsford. At 8.0 feet, Low lying portions of South Creek Road will flood in Clarendon between Walker Mountain Road and Wallingford. In Pittsford, Elm Street and Depot Road will be under water. Field flooding will occur along Dorr Drive in Rutland, along with lowland flooding upstream to Wallingford and downstream to Pittsford. At 9.0 feet, In Clarendon, low lying portions of South Creek Rd. will flood between Walker Mountain Rd. and Wallingford, and water will approach Alfrecha Rd. In Pittsford, Elm St. and Depot Hill Rd. will begin to flood. Field flooding will occur along Dorr Dr. in Rutland, along with lowland flooding upstream to Wallingford and downstream to Pittsford. At 10.0 feet, In Rutland, flooding will occur on low lying roads including Dorr Drive, Park Street and Clement Road. High water will also approach Meadow Street and the adjacent recreation fields will flood. Alfrecha Road in Clarendon will flood. Water will approach homes on West Proctor Road near Route 4 in Rutland. Downstream in Proctor and Pittsford, numerous roads will flood, along with Route 73 west of Brandon. At 11.0 feet, Water will come near homes and businesses in Rutland along Otter Creek on Dorr Dr., Park St., Meadow St., Clement Rd., and along the confluence of Otter Creek and the Clarendon River at West Proctor Rd. and Rte 4. Low lying roads in Clarendon and Wallingford will flood. Downstream in Proctor and Pittsford, numerous roads will be inundated, including Elm St., Willow St. and Depot Hill Road. Route 73 west of Brandon will flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:45 PM EST Thursday the stage was 9.7 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 6:45 PM EST Thursday was 9.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.8 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.7 feet on 12/26/2020. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 2:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A deep arctic trough will move south over the Western Interior and West Coast and bring well below normal temperatures beginning Friday night. Low temperatures by Saturday morning will be in the teens and 20s below zero and remain that way through Wednesday morning. Highs will range from near zero to 10 below. North winds of 10 to 30 mph with higher gusts in normally channeled areas including Shaktoolik, Johnson's Camp, and the Bering Strait are expected starting Friday night and lasting through the middle of next week as well. This, combined with lows dropping into the teens and 20s below zero, will bring wind chills into the 20s to 40s below zero by Friday night, with widepread wind chills of 35 to 45 below zero by Monday morning.
Residents and those traveling in the area are encouraged to be prepared for much colder than normal conditions.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:59PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary: An upper level disturbance will work together with a backdoor cold front to produce an area of snow showers midday Friday through late Friday night along the spine of the central mountain chain and the Continental Divide. Locally higher snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches an hour along with reduced visibility could be possible in any heavier showers. Snow showers should quickly taper off early Saturday morning as overall lift and moisture decreases.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 7 at 1:48PM AKST until March 9 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW FOR HAINES HIGHWAY AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS...
.Heavy snow beginning tonight will move into the Haines and Haines Highway area. Warm moisture will overrun cooler air at the surface, producing heavy snow and raising snow levels over time. As the warm air moves over Haines, snow will become increasingly wet and heavy, limiting snow totals. For areas 600 feet and above, such as Haines Customs, precipitation is expected to stay as snow and accumulate up to 12 inches.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 8 to 12 inches.
* WHERE...Haines Highway above 600 ft.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to midnight AKST Friday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult and is discouraged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Highest snowfall rates around Haines Customs is expected to be Friday morning with rates around 0.5 to 0.75 inches per hour.

* WINDS...Northwest 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.

* TEMPERATURES...Up to 88.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 7 at 1:42PM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
ESFSEW
A series of storm systems will spread moderate to heavy rainfall across Western Washington this weekend and into early next week. Storm total rainfall amounts of 3 to 6 inches are possible across the Olympic Peninsula. Snow levels near 2500-3000 ft may limit runoff amounts. This amount of prolonged rainfall has the potential to push the Skokomish River into flood stage.
Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 7 at 2:11PM CST by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
A period of steady rainfall is expected to move into the area on Friday, lingering into the evening. Widespread rainfall amounts up to one inch are possible across northeast Illinois and northwest Indiana, with amounts of 1-2 inches possible in isolated areas. Dormant vegetation and elevated soil moisture conditions will reduce infiltration and allow for much of this rainfall to runoff into area streams and rivers.
Ensemble river forecast guidance indicates the possibility of multiple rivers reaching bankfull due to this rainfall. Urban areas and poor drainage areas may also experience areas of standing water. While widespread flooding is not likely, a few river locations may near flood stage by this weekend.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
An update to this outlook will be issued by tomorrow morning.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 7 at 12:17PM CST until March 9 at 3:00PM CST by NWS Birmingham AL
entry.summary:
Heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding is expected to arrive as early as midday Friday and may persist through Saturday afternoon. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches with locally higher amounts are likely. Heavy rainfall that occurs is expected to rapidly run off due to fairly wet soil conditions currently in place across central Alabama. Flash flooding will be possible as a result, along with rises on small streams and drainage basins.
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of central Alabama, including the following counties, Autauga, Barbour, Bibb, Blount, Bullock, Calhoun, Chambers, Cherokee, Chilton, Clay, Cleburne, Coosa, Dallas, Elmore, Etowah, Fayette, Greene, Hale, Jefferson, Lamar, Lee, Lowndes, Macon, Marengo, Marion, Montgomery, Perry, Pickens, Pike, Randolph, Russell, Shelby, St. Clair, Sumter, Talladega, Tallapoosa, Tuscaloosa, Walker and Winston.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued March 8 at 3:13AM ChST until March 11 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, Large breaking waves of 10 to 12 feet, building to 13 feet over the weekend. For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding expected.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Monday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, from this afternoon through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is expected starting this afternoon, especially during high tide. Greatest risk will be along shores exposed to the northeast to east across the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher around the Marshall Islands. Please report any inundation to the local Weather Service Office (WSO).

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:17AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A deep arctic trough will move south over the Western Interior and West Coast and bring well below normal temperatures beginning Friday night. High pressure over the Chukchi Sea will bring strong north winds starting Friday night as well. Low temperatures by Saturday morning will be in the teens and 20s below zero and remain that way through Wednesday morning. Highs will range from near zero to 10 below. North winds of 10 to 30 mph with higher gusts will bring wind chills as low as the 40s to near 50 below zero.
Residents and those traveling in the area are encouraged to be prepared for much colder than normal conditions.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 6 at 3:01PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
ESFBIS
Given the recent cold weather, the Missouri River has again been forming ice below Garrison Dam. Thus far, ice has filled the recently cleared portion of the Missouri River from roughly Apple Creek Wildlife Management Area to about three-fourths of a mile upstream of where 12th street southeast turns into Oahe Bend. This would roughly be equal to a little less than five miles of new ice in the river.
The upstream edge of immobile ice as of Wednesday morning was roughly three and a half miles downstream of Fort Abraham Lincoln and Fox Island. While the future rate of ice formation is difficult to predict, forecast overnight lows in the single digits for both Thursday and Friday mornings will continue to encourage ice formation. It should be expected that the upstream edge of continuous ice on the river will migrate upstream. Based on how much ice has already been put in place, it is possible that the upstream edge of continuous ice will reach the Fox Island area before warmer weather enters the area on Friday. By late Saturday, warmer weather will once again reverse this process and start removing ice.
Importantly, pre-ice river levels were about 3.5 feet below that observed prior to last week's ice jam due to already planned lower releases out of Garrison Dam. This suggests that a return to water levels experienced in late February is not likely.

cap:parameter.value: MISSOURI RIVER IS ONCE AGAIN MAKING ICE
